title: 346-B
statement: B. Lucky Common Subsequencetime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test512 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutIn mathematics, asubsequenceis a sequence that can be derived from another sequence by deleting some elements without changing the order of the remaining elements. For example, the sequenceBDFis a subsequence ofABCDEF. Asubstringof a string is a continuous subsequence of the string. For example,BCDis a substring ofABCDEF.You are given two stringss1,s2and another string calledvirus. Your task is to find the longest common subsequence ofs1ands2, such that it doesn't containvirusas a substring.InputThe input contains three strings in three separate lines:s1,s2andvirus(1 ≤ |s1|, |s2|, |virus| ≤ 100). Each string consists only of uppercase English letters.OutputOutput the longest common subsequence ofs1ands2withoutvirusas a substring. If there are multiple answers, any of them will be accepted.If there is no valid common subsequence, output 0.ExamplesInputAJKEQSLOBSROFGZOVGURWZLWVLUXTHOZOutputORZInputAAAAOutput0

processed.result: You are given three strings:  $s_1$, $s_2$, and $virus$.  Find the longest subsequence that is common to both $s_1$ and $s_2$, but does not contain $virus$ as a substring. If no such subsequence exists, output 0.
Given three strings, find the longest string that appears in both of the first two strings but not in the third string. If no such string exists, output 0.
